issues.title: Use log levels to turn on debug mode on bigbluebutton-api-ruby
issues.body: When a `BigBlueButtonApi` object is created, it receives a flag to turn on/off the debug mode. Currently BigbluebuttonRails will always set it as false, but it could use the current log level set on Rails to turn it on (if the level is "debug").

issues.title: Remove unavailable recordings after being unavailable for some time
issues.body:
Recordings that are not available in the web conference server are kept in the database and marked as unavailable. This is done to prevent issues in case the server is not responding for a short time, for example.

However, keeping the unavailable recordings in the database for ever is not a good thing. If a recording is removed from the web conference server manually, for example, it will not be removed from the database and will be there until someone manually deletes it.

There could be a maximum amount of time that unavailable recordings are kept in the database before they are removed automatically. A worker could do it in background and remove recordings that were marked as unavailable e.g. 7+ days ago.

issues.title: Remove sleeps from workers, use schedules
issues.body:
Some workers have sleep calls inside of them, to wait for a while before executing. See https://github.com/mconf/bigbluebutton_rails/blob/master/app/workers/bigbluebutton_meeting_updater.rb#L9

This is bad because it locks the worker until the sleep is done, so the overall time it takes to run the worker is the process time plus the sleep time. Workers that take longer are bad because there is usually a limited amount of workers processing jobs in an application.

There are better ways of doing it using resque. One of the possibilities is to use resque-scheduler to schedule the execution of the worker, so the wait will be done by the scheduler and will not have any influence in the time it takes to run the worker.

issues.title: Update meeting records after calls to getMeetings
issues.body:
Meeting records are currently created and edited whenever a call to `getMeetingInfo` is made. Using the attributes in the response, the meeting record is created or edited, including being set as "ended".

Calls to `getMeetings` have a response very similar to the response of `getMeetingInfo`, including most of the attributes necessary to update meetings or even consider them ended. So these calls could also be used to create/edit meetings.

issues.title: Should not require the user model to have the attribute "username"
issues.body:
The gem is requiring the user model of the application that uses the gem to have a method/attribute named `username`, but it shouldn't. The specific place where it's required is at: https://github.com/mconf/bigbluebutton_rails/blob/6a017a78248d08f40d2b53ef52a4e6524f91be49/app/controllers/bigbluebutton/rooms_controller.rb#L343
There might be other places, though.

There are configurable attributes in the gem to specify the name of the attribute from where the username should be taken, see https://github.com/mconf/bigbluebutton_rails/blob/6a017a78248d08f40d2b53ef52a4e6524f91be49/lib/bigbluebutton_rails.rb#L66

issues.title: Increase the precision of some datetime attributes
issues.body:
Some of the dates returned by the web conference server are being stored in the database as a `datetime`, even though they are returned as a timestamp (with 13 digits).
Some other dates are already being stored with a higher precision, as for example `t.decimal :create_time, precision: 14, scale: 0`.

The following dates should also be stored as decimal to increase their precision:
- `BigbluebuttonRecording#start_time`
- `BigbluebuttonRecording#end_time`
- `BigbluebuttonMeeting#create_time`

issues.title: Remove external rooms
issues.body:
External rooms are rooms that exist in the web conference server but that are not in the database. This happens only when meetings are created in the web conference server using something else other than Mconf-Web.

This feature is very likely not used at all and brings some extra complexity to the code. For instance, any operation over a room that changes attributes and saves the room needs to check whether the room is already in the database or not (`new_record?`).
If external rooms are really not used, removing it would make the gem a bit simpler.

issues.title: Hash user IDs when passing to API calls
issues.body: Instead of passing the user's ID directly as the parameter `userID` in `join` API calls ([see this](https://github.com/mconf/bigbluebutton_rails/blob/master/app/models/bigbluebutton_room.rb#L491)), the gem could hash this ID with something like `sha1` to make sure the actual ID that comes from the database is not leaked while still make sure it's unique and always the same for users that have the same ID.

With that, all calls to fetch_recordings that had filters would make all

Centralize the process of ending meetings after get_meeting_info

Instead of doing it in a worker and in lib/background_tasks, now it is
centralized in the method BigbluebuttonRoom#fetch_meeting_info.
It will check for exceptions and mark the meeting as ended.

Now it also has a way to reopen meetings. It is useful in case the server
stops responding and the meeting is marked as ended. Previously it would
be ended forever and a new meeting record would be created if the server
started responding again.

One last change is that it now considers any BigBlueButtonException to end
the meeting, not just the ones with the key 'notFound'. This works better
now since it can also reopen ended meetings if needed.

refs #1787

Better logic and more tests for auto setting API version

Added several tests that describe how the feature should work. In short,
the version of the API of a server is automatically fetched from the server
if the BigbluebuttonServer doesn't have a version set or if it's empty.
So, to get the version from the server, is enough to just save the server
with version=nil. And the user can still force set a version on it if
he wishes to.

Only does it when updating the server. If a server has no version set for
some reason (e.g. legacy db), it will cause it to fetch the API version
from the server after each request. To end it, just save the server.

refs #1142

Don't generate voice bridges, let the webconf server generate it

Now the gem will not set the voice bridge parameter when creating a meeting.
Doing so, the web conference server will generate it for us.
It's the easiest way to solve problems with duplicated voice bridges, an issue
that would happen on an instance of Mconf-Web with 9999 rooms or more.
Since the web conference server knows only of meetings that are running, now
the limit was expanded to 99999 *simultaneous* rooms/meetings.

There is still a parameter in the gem that can be set in case an application
wants to use the voice bridges set in the gem.

Unifying actions 'join' and 'auth' and breaking 'join' in blocks

Now there's a single action to join meetings: 'join'. It can be called via
GET or POST, and accepts the parameters as previously accepted by 'auth'
(user's name and password).
Also, 'join' is now broken in several smaller methods (before filters) to make
it simpler.

This was all done to make the join process in mobile devices better. We need
to display the 'join_mobile' view as an intermediary step when joining from
mobile devices. And it needs to be done when joining directly from 'join' or
from 'invite', and previously was done only for 'join'.

  unit.rb:740:in `sort_by': comparison of String with nil failed (ArgumentError)
Update ruby to 1.9.3-p484
Update bigbluebutton-api-ruby and get it from master using https

Prevent rooms from having no room_options associated

If a room has no room_options associated yet, it will be created whenever
it is accessed.
Useful especially when migrating an old database that already has rooms in it.

refs #962

Fixes for setting the config.xml, complements fba43b3dd73

Wasn't setting the modified config.xml appropriately and was modifying the
properties even if they were nil/empty in the BigbluebuttonRoomOptions.

refs #962
Add .bundle/ to .gitignore

Fix the mobile urls generated in 'join_mobile'

Was using the protocol 'bigbluebutton://' in a url that shouldn't use it.
The error happened only when using http, not with https.
Now it uses 'bigbluebutton://' only in the QR code and works with whatever
protocol is used in the application.

Add tests and small improvements for config.xml related features

Added tests for everything new implemented for #962.
And improved the getting of a config token before joining to reduce the number
of API calls when possible (if nothing was set in the room options or if the
XML generated is equal the default XML).

refs #962

Pass configToken to join calls, fully functional

Made the last changes to pass the configToken to join calls. Also added the
complete list of layouts available in BigBlueButton/Mconf-Live.

refs #962

This improves the way a server is selected, but doesn't solve the biggest issue on #1475. The biggest problem is having rooms without a server and having to manually set a server to them.

The call to `select_server` is only made when a meeting is being created in a room. But other API methods are usually called before it (e.g. `is_meeting_running?`). So, if the room has no server, it will break even before it tries to create a meeting.

Why exactly do you think calling `select_server` inside `require_server` would complicate overriding `select_server`?
I think it would be just as easy to override it as it is now. The only difference is that it will be called a lot more.

It could be even improved a bit more to be something like this:
- `require_server` receives a parameter that should be the API call that's being called (e.g. `:create`, `:is_meeting_running`)
- `require_server` **always** calls `select_server` passing the API method. If a server is returned, it sets the server in the room and saves the room. Otherwise it doesn't do anything.
- If the room has no server at the end of this, `require_server` should still raise an exception (as it does today).
- `select_server` by default should only select a server if the room has no server yet. Otherwise it returns `nil`.

This seems flexible enough for people to override `select_server` and decide when it has to change the server of a room and when it doesn't need to.
By default it will also make sure that a room always has a server before any API call is made.

What do you think?

Have you tried using this with Mconf-Web?
Try to use it there, set a default layout to a meeting and check if it will work. I think it won't.

Take, for example, the `presentfocus: "Webinar"`.
I think Mconf-Web will show the list of layouts with their localized name ("Webinar"), but it will also use this localized name when storing the default layout in the database. When creating a meeting, it will set the layout as "Webinar", but BigBlueButton won't recognize it. It would only recognize the key "presentfocus".

The solution I see is to have a separate method that returns the localized layouts. Something like `available_layouts_names`. Mconf-Web will then have to be adapted to use both `available_layouts` and `available_layouts_names`, whenever appropriate.

I also think `available_layouts_names` should be on `BigbluebuttonServerConfig`, the model that actually stores the layouts. `BigbluebuttonServer` and `BigbluebuttonRoom` can then just delegate to it.
Thank you :smile:

You could have a single method `internal_password` to replace `internal_moderator_password` and `internal_attendee_password`. And it can be a private method.

ps: `unique_meetingid` is not private because it can possibly be used by the application that uses the gem. For the internal passwords I don't think we need this.

The problem of not generating `moderator_api_password` and `attendee_api_password` in the factory is in tests like this one. When it gets here, `moderator_api_password` is probably nil, so it's not really testing that the correct password is passed.
We have to consider adding the internal passwords to the factory... Not sure if it's better or not.

Not wrong, but it doesn't clearly test what has to be tested.
See the suggestion below. The key points are: 1) expecting that `internal_attendee_password` and `internal_moderator_password` are called and 2) expecting the return of these methods to be used in the parameters when calling `send_create`.

``` ruby
context "always generate new passwords" do
  let(:moderator_password) { Forgery(:basic).password }
  let(:attendee_password) { Forgery(:basic).password }
  before do
    room.should_receive(:internal_moderator_password).and_return(moderator_password)
    room.should_receive(:internal_attendee_password).and_return(attendee_password)

    params = get_create_params(room)
    params[:attendeePW] = moderator_password
    params[:moderatorPW] = attendee_password
    mocked_api.should_receive(:create_meeting)
      .with(room.name, room.meetingid, params)
      .and_return(hash_create)

    room.stub(:select_server).and_return(mocked_server)
    room.server = mocked_server
  end
  it { room.send_create }
end
```

It looks more like the test "generates a meetingid if nil" now.

You should add a new test to make sure `createTime` is included in the join url. Take a look at this test:

``` ruby
  context "if the token is not nil" do
```

You mixed the tests for `createTime` with the tests for `configToken`. Try to make them separately.
You can use `hash_not_including` here to make sure the `configToken` is **not** set. The other values on the hash don't matter.
Then in the tests for `createTime` only you can do the same: one that checks that the `createTime` is set and another that checks that it isn't set.

issues.title: Only suggest instead of requiring versions of BigBlueButton
issues.body:
---

Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Redmine Issue: 1957, http://dev.mconf.org/redmine/issues/1957

---

The gem currently requires the version of BigBlueButton to be one of the versions listed in it, see https://github.com/mconf/bigbluebutton_rails/blob/v2.0.0/app/models/bigbluebutton_server.rb#L49

Given the stability of the API, it would be better to just suggest these versions, but allow the user to use the gem with other versions as well. This would also help when newer versions of the API are released.

Also, the list of versions supported could be taken from bigbluebutton-api-ruby, see https://github.com/mconf/bigbluebutton-api-ruby/blob/v1.5.0/lib/bigbluebutton_api.rb#L71

issues.title: Improve treatment of exceptions raised by bigbluebutton-api-ruby
issues.body:
---

Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Redmine Issue: 1949, http://dev.mconf.org/redmine/issues/1949

---

Several places in the gem where bigbluebutton-api-ruby is used, there's a "begin rescue" block to prevent raising exceptions in case of API failures.
This is good, since we want to treat the exceptions instead of raising them to the user, but at the same time most of these "begin rescue" are hiding the real exception, even for administrators. We should review all places where exceptions are caught and, at least, print the exception to the log files.

Also, API calls that result in errors (checksum errors, for instance) should not get to the user as a "checksum error", but as a more generic "API error", while still being logged as the full error.

issues.title: Improve the error shown to users on invalid API call responses
issues.body:
---

Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Redmine Issue: 1849, http://dev.mconf.org/redmine/issues/1849

---

When the gem makes a request to the web conference server that comes with an invalid response (not an XML or an invalid XML), it will raise an exception similar to:

```
Impossible to convert XML to hash. Error: Missing end tag for 'hr' (got "body") Line: 6 Position: 168 Last 80 unconsumed characters: 

```

This is ok for the application to know and log, but it's a bad message to show to users.
Users should receive a more generic message similar to: "the web conference server is not responding properly, check the configurations or try again later".

issues.body:
---

Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Redmine Issue: 633, http://dev.mconf.org/redmine/issues/633
Original Date: 2013-03-12

---

Review all json responses to standardize the returned objects.

Currently, most of them return a json object with a message only. We could replace it by the object that was created/updated or by an empty object in actions that destroy the objects.
Returning the object is useful when updating it via json, like is done when jEditable is used. In an update, for example, it expects the object to be returned so that it can confirm that the new value of the attribute it tried to set was actually set.

issues.title: Consider storing all fetched attributes in the DB
issues.body:
---

Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Redmine Issue: 154, http://dev.mconf.org/redmine/issues/154

---

@Google user: leonardo...@gmail.com@

Consider if all the information fetched from a BBB server should be saved in the DB or not. Some of this information is stored only in instance variables in the models, so they are lost between requests. Saving them is the only way to fully compare models between two requests.
- For rooms the attributes are: running, participant_count, moderator_count, attendees, has_been_forcibly_ended, start_time, end_time.
- Servers have only the attribute "meetings", but it is already saved as BigbluebuttonRoom's models.

There are some complications in saving "attendees", since they are objects with their own attributes. It would require another table for attendees and the setting up of the relationship between attendees and rooms.

issues.title: Problems for bigbluebutton_rails when meetings are created from another system
issues.body:
---

Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Redmine Issue: 153, http://dev.mconf.org/redmine/issues/153

---

@Google user: leonardo...@gmail.com@

This ticket was created to keep track of potencial problems for bigbluebutton_rails when another system is also used to create/manage BBB meetings.

When the list of meetings is fetched from a BBB server, any meeting that is not yet in the database will be created and saved. If the room is already in the DB, its attributes will be updated. See "https://github.com/mconf/bigbluebutton_rails/commit/02b472f82bbe52f2d753c67a55341268de374395" rel="nofollow":https://github.com/mconf/bigbluebutton_rails/commit/02b472f82bbe52f2d753c67a55341268de374395 

If the meeting was not in the DB it means that it was created from another application (BBB demos, Android client, etc). This raises two issues:
- Since we didn't create the meeting, we don't have all the parameters passed in the creation. Unfortunately there are some parameters you can't access through the API after creating a meeting. So there will probably be inconsistencies in these parameters between the meeting in the DB and the meeting running in the server. These parameters are:
  - welcome (the welcome message)
  - voiceBridge
  - logoutURL
  - maxParticipants
- Adding or updating this meeting in the DB might result in conflicts with already existent meetings.

@BigbluebuttonRecording.sync@ actually only syncs the recordings passed to it, so it's not requesting the recordings to all servers (as was suggested in the description). If it throws an exception, it will be shown to the user as a general error when in production (nothing wrong with this). And the error should be logged so that an admin/developer can check it.

We could in the future improve the message that shows the recordings that were actually updated/created/removed and also add new tools for admins to debug errors that might occur. But for now nothing will be changed.

We decided that:

-> We assume that recordings will _never_ have duplicated IDs. The ID is a hash (generated from the meetingID) plus a timestamp. To have duplicated recordIDs, two meetings have to start at the exact same time using the same meetingID in two different servers. Possible but very unlikely to happen.

This information will be included in the wiki in the future, see issue #576.

Comment about issue #554:

If there are recordings with the same recordID in two different servers, what will happen when recordings are synchronised in the db? Currently the recordID of a recordings is unique, so probably only the first recording will be saved.
-> We assume that recordings will _never_ have duplicated IDs. The ID is a hash (generated from the meetingID) plus a timestamp. To have duplicated recordIDs, two meetings have to start at the exact same time using the same meetingID in two different servers. Possible but very unlikely to happen.

Original Redmine Comment
Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Date: 2013-06-12T18:54:23Z

---

This has been discussed in BigBlueButton's mailing list and the idea has changed a lot from the original idea described in this issue. See https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/bigbluebutton-dev/Cz9zcPbRZfI/CLX1IdQgA9AJ

The current version of @BigbluebuttonRails@ uses unique global meetingIDs for conferences and so the generation of random meetingIDs was removed.
With static meetingIDs the problem we have is what is described in this issue: https://code.google.com/p/bigbluebutton/issues/detail?id=1324
In short, a meeting that finish can stay in memory in the BigBlueButton server for a while, and while it is there the user won't be able to create the meeting again with, for example, different parameters to set the record flag.

The proposed solution is:
- Check if the meeting is running. If it is, we don't need to create the meeting again.
- If it is not running, call 'end' to finish the old meeting and only then create it again.

This has to be implemented and tested against a real server.

---

Original Redmine Comment
Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Date: 2014-08-12T16:18:39Z

---

Checking if a meeting is running or not is not always ideal. A meeting can be in memory but not running if there's no one in it. A better solution would be to find if the meeting is in memory or not.

So the gem should either:
1. Call @end@ always in case the meeting is not running (as proposed in the comment above); or
2. Instead of calling @isMeetingRunning@ to check if the meeting is running, the gem could call @getMeetingInfo@. It would also have the @running@ flag in it, but would also indicate whether the meeting is created (in memory) or not. If it is in memory (running or not), the gem should call an @end@ first. Otherwise it doesn't need to call @end@.

---

Original Redmine Comment
Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Date: 2013-11-04T18:25:14Z

---

Done mostly using resque workers. A worker is schedule to run a few seconds after one of the events below happens:
- A "create" API call is sent
- An "end" API call is sent
- A user will be redirected to join a meeting

The worker will call "getMeetingInfo" in the target room to see if the meeting is running or not, and create the @BigbluebuttonMeeting@ model if needed.

There's also a rake task that runs in cron every ~10 minutes to synchronize the list of meetings, and especially to mark meetings as "not running" after they finish (since we don't have a way of knowing if a meeting ended unless a call to "end" is made).

Meetings are also associated with recordings, so the application can know the meeting that generated a given recording.

TODOs for the future:
- The worker currently only tries to get information of a meeting once. If the meeting takes longer than the time the worker waits before running, the worker won't find the meeting in the web conference server. Maybe it should try more that once to find the meeting (or simply trigger another worker if it fails, until it finds something). See #1065.
- List meetings and add actions to modify and remove them. See #1066.
- Currently meetings are never removed from the db. We might have to give options to an administrator to remove old meetings that are not necessary anymore.

---

Original Redmine Comment
Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Date: 2015-01-19T16:59:24Z

---

Let's go with the second option only for now: create a resque task to update the options.

It could run once every 2 hours. It should get the default config.xml and update the options accordingly. For now it will only get the list of layouts available, but it should be done in a way that it's easy enough to make it update all the rest that is available in the config.xml.

This options are currently in the model BigbluebuttonRoomOptions, that is associated to BigbluebuttonRoom. The list of layouts (and everything else from config.xml) is actually related to the server and not the room. If the room changes to another server, this information should be updated.
So we should also transfer this information to a model that's associated with BigbluebuttonServer. BigbluebuttonRoom can still have the same functions it has today, but they should get information from the room's server.

---

Original Redmine Comment
Author Name: **Leonardo Daronco** (Leonardo Daronco)
Original Date: 2015-01-19T17:07:59Z

---

We should also seize the oportunity for all calls we make to @getDefaultConfigXML@ and update the db with the information we got from the config.xml (see https://github.com/mconf/bigbluebutton_rails/blob/branch-v1.4.0/app/models/bigbluebutton_room.rb#L351).

This would allow an admin to "force" an update: creating a meeting in a room that has custom information set on its options will trigger a @getDefaultConfigXML@, and with it will also trigger an update in the information in the db.

commits.message: Added a log when the room was successfully created.

Improve the options to playback/download recordings

refs #1482

Better names for playback types

Some modifications were made to let users change the playback types names. Moreover it's possible to set if some playback types are visible or not to users.

Refs #1142
Renamed identifiers to work with the new version.
Removed the name uniqueness requirement for bigbluebutton room.
Update rooms_controller_spec.rb
Update rooms_controller.rb
Improved the way how the metadatas are sent from the fetch meetings info.

Initial changes to use dynamic config.xml to join meetings with a specific configuration

Created a new function in bigbluebutton_room model to generate a new token with all configurations changed by the user.

Refs #962

Update rooms_controller.rb

Adding a restriction for allowed parameters on rooms. Now the parameter default_layouts can be modified.

Refs #962

Created a way to let users change the layout of the rooms.

To do this, a new model was created to receive the options from the room. In this model a user can set the default layout who he wanted. A new function was created in this model to return all the layouts allowed in the server, for now this function just return a list of fixed layouts.

Refs #962
Add more tests

Correct an error in the condition used to force the update

refs #1686
Correct minor mistake when raising error from invalid version
Add/modify tests to reflect new functionality

Automatically set the version number

The version number is fetched from the server when the user
creates/updates it, except if a version is informed. In
the latter case, the informed version is used. When the
server's url or salt is changed it also checks the new
version and updates it.

refs #1686
Add the new fields to the gem's show and index views

Add BBB 0.9's parameters to BBBRoom model

Now these parameters are used in the relevant API calls. If they're
nil, they will be discarded by the callers, so we don't need to
worry about that here.
Also included BBB 0.9 in the list of accepted versions.

refs #1637

Differentiate available_layouts and available_layouts_names

This allows us to zip them together in [name, id] pairs. These,
when passed to a form's select control, will show the name but
use the id when saving it to the database, and this fixes our problem.

refs #1571

Change behavior of require_server

Now when we call it on a room that has no server associated,
it selects one through select_server. An exception is raised
if there are no servers available to be selected.

refs #1475

Call send_end when creating a meeting

If the meeting is not running, we call send_end in order to
free it from memory before creating it again, thus inhibiting
occurences of duplicateWarning and idNotUnique.

refs #606
Add tests

Use translation when displaying available layouts

Intercepted the call to available_layouts in BigbluebuttonRoom, instead
of delegating it directly to BigbluebuttonServer, in order to translate
it before returning.

refs #1571
Improve readability of test

Change the way that recordings are set as unavailable

Now updates only the records of the server being synced.
Tests ensure that recordings from other servers aren't set as unavailable.

refs #915

Change server selection method

Previously it wouldn't select a server without any rooms. Now it does.
Also, the translation key in require_server was wrong. Fixed it.

refs #1475
Add tests on new model

Use serialization on available_layouts

Also, simplify the get_config method on BigbluebuttonServer and treat the exception that may be
raised by update_config if the url of the server is invalid.

refs #1140

Add update of server's configs

Added a rake task to fetch the servers' configurations from the server.
Also, added callbacks on server creation and url update with the same purpose.

refs #1141

Added Resque task that fetches the configs periodically.

Task is run once every three hours.

refs #1140

Removed the commands to run migration 2.0.1

It doesn't exist anymore, its changes have been merged into the migration 2.0.0

Now updates the DB model of BigbluebuttonServerConfig

Also, instead of creating a new migration, included the creation of the new table
in the one that already existed (2.0.0).

Changed some tests.

Also, one function call in bigbluebutton_room.rb was in the wrong place.

Now saves Server configurations locally

The only configuration being saved right now is the set of available layouts for the servers' rooms. This info is being saved in the BigbluebuttonServerConfig model.

Ok it somehow resolved itself on v2. I guess it was a ruby/rails version issue. Thanks anyway. Closing the issue.

I found a solution for the PG error; just replace the parameter in the group_by clause. The second line of the query should look like this:

```
joins(:rooms).group("bigbluebutton_servers.id").order("room_count ASC").first
```

I can create a pull request for this but I dont have a mysql server setup and so wont be able to test against that. 

Hopefully that helped though it is 2 years too late.

@pandugreycampus, I have this error, when I use `gem 'bigbluebutton_rails'`.

In bigbluebutton_rails migration I don't have `bigbluebutton_server_configs` table.

I remove all (rollback db too).

Add `gem 'bigbluebutton_rails', github: 'mconf/bigbluebutton_rails'` to Gemfile.
`bundle`
and when  I use `rails generate bigbluebutton_rails:install`, in migration I have table 

```
    create_table :bigbluebutton_server_configs do |t|
      t.integer :server_id
      t.text :available_layouts
      t.timestamps
    end
```

And now I can create server on PG database.
